qas.question: Which philosophy attempted to reconcile Aristotelian teachings and Christian theology in the 13th century?
Where was the Condemnation of 1277 enacted?
Which philosopher believed that reason and faith were to be kept separate?
What is the common name for William of Ockham's principle of parsimony?
On what types of ideas did the Condemnation of 1277 place restrictions?
Which philosophy attempted to reconcile Aristotelian teachings and Christian theology in the 12th century?
Where was the Condemnation of 1727 enacted?
Which philosopher believed that reason and faith were to be kept together?
What is the uncommon name for William of Ockham's principle of parsimony?
On what types of ideas did the Condemnation of 1272 place restrictions?

context: The predominant school of thought in the 13th century was the <a0_0><b5_0>Thomistic<b5_0/><a0_0/> reconciliation of the teachings of Aristotle with Christian theology. The Condemnation of 1277, enacted at the <a1_0><b6_0>University of Paris<b6_0/><a1_0/>, placed restrictions on ideas that could be interpreted as <a4_0><b9_0>heretical<b9_0/><a4_0/>; restrictions that had implication for Aristotelian thought. An alternative was presented by <a2_0><b7_0>William of Ockham<b7_0/><a2_0/>, who insisted that the world of reason and the world of faith had to be kept apart. Ockham introduced the principle of parsimony – or <a3_0><b8_0>Occam's razor<b8_0/><a3_0/> – whereby a simple theory is preferred to a more complex one, and speculation on unobservable phenomena is avoided.
